summary: On June 4, 2019, the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan entered a final judgment against Weaam Nocha, the sole shareholder of a Michigan-based medical marijuana dispensary, for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The court also found that the Debtor had full authority to enter into a bankruptcy case without the consent of his wife, Rafaa Nocha.  According to the court's order, the Debt filed this bankruptcy case for the sole purpose of evading the September 2016 judgment that imposed a 2-year bar to the filing of a new bankruptcy case.  In its judgment, the court found that weaam nocha had full control over the Nocha Property, and that he had the right to apply for and obtain possession of the property as part of a common design to operate a marijuana dispensary at the property.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the Court's judgment, Weaamm Nocha consented to the entry of a final judgement that permanently enjoins him from violating the federal securities laws, and orders him to pay disgorgement of $1.2 million, prejudgment interest of $600,000, and a civil penalty of $100,000.  He also agreed to be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company for a period of two years, and to be enjoined from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any securities in connection with the sale of that company's securities.  On June 5, 2020, the Court granted a temporary restraining order and ordered a hearing on the matter to determine whether to proceed with a judgment imposing a permanent injunction, ordering a hearing in the matter, and appointing a receiver to determine the amount of relief to be granted by the court upon motion of the court.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-01-2019.  Separately, the Department of Justice today announced that it has issued an order suspending the asset freeze and asset freeze provisions of Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4) of itsÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them investments using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.Â  The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has also issued an Investor Alert on the subject of this matter, warning investors to be aware of the risks associated with filing a bankruptcy with the SEC.
